content.headline: Essential Guide to Breastfeeding: From Basics to Challenges
content.intro: Breastfeeding is when you feed your baby milk that comes from your body. Experts recommend breastfeeding as your baby's only source of nutrition until age 6 months, whenever possible. This provides nutrients and antibodies to support your baby's health.

sections.title: The Five Basic Steps of Breastfeeding
sections.content: Follow these essential steps for successful breastfeeding:
points: Find a comfortable breastfeeding position that brings your baby close to you
Guide your baby's mouth to your nipple, pointing toward their nose
Help your baby latch on with mouth wide open covering most of the areola
Let your baby settle into a rhythm of suckling and short pauses
Burp your baby after they break their latch or turn away from your breast

sections.title: How Breastfeeding Works
sections.content: Understanding the lactation process helps you succeed:
points: Baby's suckling stimulates nerves that release prolactin and oxytocin
Prolactin tells your alveoli to make milk
Oxytocin triggers milk let-down into milk ducts
Lactation works on supply and demand basis
Your body takes cues from your baby's feeding patterns

sections.title: What to Avoid While Breastfeeding
sections.content: Limit or avoid these substances for your baby's safety:
points: Limit caffeine to less than 300 milligrams per day
Limit alcohol and drink at least 2 hours before nursing
Avoid fish with high mercury levels like shark and swordfish
Avoid nicotine and marijuana completely
Consult your provider before taking any medications

sections.title: Common Breastfeeding Challenges
sections.content: Many mothers face these issues - help is available:
points: Breast engorgement and milk supply issues
Clogged milk ducts and mastitis
Sore, cracked or painful nipples
Latching difficulties
Challenges with pumping and expressing milk

sections.title: Getting Professional Support
sections.content: Don't hesitate to seek help from these specialists:
points: Breastfeeding medicine specialists for complex issues
International Board Certified Lactation Consultants
Breastfeeding educators and counselors
Your primary care provider or obstetrician
Breastfeeding peer supporters with personal experience
